awd_titl_txt: An ultra-sensitive micro sensor for biophysical studies of single cells cultured in 3D extracellular matrix
awd_abstract_narration:
Considerable experimental evidence acquired during the last three decades has now established that living cells are contractile. They generate force on 3D tissues or 2D substrates. Forces and matrix stiffness have a profound influence on a wide range of cell behavior such as growth, motility, and differentiation. More recently, it is appreciated that cells not only respond to these cues from their 3D matrix, but also remodel the matrix and hence influence the subsequent cues. Cancer cells exploit such reciprocity within the tumor to support their metastatic journey. The precise role of mechanics in determining this reciprocity remains elusive. For example, how cells transduce mechanical cues into biochemical processes and vice versa. Which processes are involved in remodeling the matrix? Probing these fundamental questions need experimental platforms that allow to evaluate cell-forces in a 3D matrix and quantify the key parameters that determine the cell-matrix dynamics. Methods to measure single cell forces on 2D have been advanced over the last three decades. Currently, there is no method available to measure cell forces in 3D. Centennial High School (Champaign) drama teacher will assist in developing a drama with high school students representing cancer development where characters will represent  cancer, fibroblast and immune cells. The scenes will mimic various stages of cancer. Research will be integrated with education through involvement of undergraduate students from minorities in research, and web dissemination. The PI has a long record of outreach activities, including multiple videos series development for students and public.  

The goal of this project is to close this gap. It will design, develop and test an ultra-sensitive (~10nN/um) micro force sensor that allows to quantify single cell force, dynamics, and extra-cellular matrix remodeling in 3D matrix. The sensor will be applied to quantify force generation and matrix remodeling by fibroblasts, and to explore force-dependent cross talk between cancer and stromal cells leading to metastatic progression. The sensor consists of two grids, one connected to a soft spring and the other to a rigid support. A droplet of liquid cell-matrix (e.g., collagen) mixture is dispensed on the grids. It fills the grids due to capillarity and forms a free-standing tissue bridging between them. The tissue contains one or a discrete number of cells depending on the questions to be addressed. The cell(s) forms adhesion with the matrix and generates force, which is sensed by the spring. The extra cellular matrix stiffness can also be obtained by the sensor by stretching the matrix. The sensor will be used to study single fibroblasts in 3D collagen for their force, dynamics and matrix remodeling. Finally, the interactions between cancer cells and cancer associated fibroblasts in 3D matrix and the role of forces on the interaction will be explored. The outreach activities will include developing a drama with high school students representing cancer development where characters will represent cancer, fibroblast and immune cells. The scenes will mimic various stages of cancer.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project made two contributions. (1) Advanced Cell Force Measurement in 3D Matrices: We developed a pioneering microscale force sensor to measure force dynamics of single cells and cell clusters in 3D extracellular matrix (ECM), and to measure stiffness (or elastic modulus) of cell-matrix systems (tissues) as a function of time. This invention has overcome a significant limitation in the field, where force measurements had been confined to 2D culture substrates. By enabling studies of cell mechanics in 3D environments, this project has opened new avenues for understanding cellular behavior in living organs under healthy and diseased conditions. (2) Tested a Key Hypothesis in Cancer Biology: Using this novel sensor, we confirmed a long-standing hypothesis in cancer biology that cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs), through complex interactions with cancer cells, exert significant mechanical forces on extracellular matrix fibers, stiffening the tumor mechanically and promoting cancer progression in tumor models in vitro. The experimental results offered transformative insights that could lead to novel cancer therapies. 

 

Intellectual merit

There is increasing experimental evidence suggesting that living cells apply mechanical force on their 3D microenvironment consisting of ECM and other cells. Cell force plays a critical role in determining a wide range of cell functions including cell division, differentiation, cell death, and cell-cell signaling. In spite of its broad significance, cell force could not be measured in 3D environment. In 3D, cells adhere to fibrous ECM, which exhibit a highly non-linear stress-strain behavior. In addition, cells remodel the ECM chemically and mechanically. Hence, ECM mechanical properties become unknown, and cell force cannot be calculated even local deformation field is known (constitutive relation being unknown). Cell forces in 3D remained a mystery for more than 3 decades.

 

We overcame this challenge, for the first time, by developing a simple micromechanical stage - a sensor with two simple microscale cantilevers, each with a grip. We dispense a droplet of a cell-ECM mixture on and between the grips. The mixture forms a capillary bridge between the grips. After ECM cures, the bridge becomes a small-scale tissue with cells embedded in 3D ECM. By controlling cell density of the mixture, one can have a single cell in the tissue, or multiple cells to form a multi-cellular system. Cell or cells adhere to the ECM and apply force on the fibers. The matrix may undergo large local strains and remodeling, but the cell force is transferred to the grips through the ECM to maintain force balance, irrespective of the local properties of the ECM. The cantilevers bend due to the force transferred to the grips. Cell force is calculated from cantilever bending and its linear spring constant. A small fraction (~5%) of the cell force is “lost” in buckling ECM fibers between the cell-ECM adhesion sites that is not sensed by the sensor cantilevers.

 

Scientific discoveries using the sensor: (1) Cell-ECM interaction. We quantified force evolution of various types of cells in 3D ECM. We discovered that their force dynamics is very different from the dynamics on 2D substrate. Most importantly, cell force in 3D is directly correlated with mechanical deformation of their nucleus, which facilitates expression of various genes that determine cell functions. (2) Cancer mechanobiology. It has long been postulated that cancer progression is facilitated by contractile forces of cancer associated fibroblasts (CAFs). However, cell forces in 3D tumors could not be measured directly, and hence the postulate could not be verified. Using our sensors, we formed cancer tumors with CAFs and cancer cells, and verified that CAFs are indeed contractile. CAFs can increase their force by several folds when stimulated by cancer cells. Increased CAF force deforms their nucleus, promoting YAP nuclear localization, and gene expressions that support cancer cells for metastatic progression. 

 

Broader Impact

The instrumentations and the methods developed in this project will be valuable in the fields of biophysics and biology, cancer research, and neuroscience. Many questions in these fields are related to mechanobiology. The cell force sensor will be used in these fields to address these questions. The array of sensors developed during the last year will be useful for testing drug efficacy on cancer tumors formed by patient’s cells. This might impact diagnosis, prognosis and personalized therapy. 

The project trained 2 PhD students and 6-8 undergraduate students. The knowledge gained in the project has been disseminated via journal publications, conference presentations, and multiple outreach programs. We presented a demonstration of a biohybrid machine made from small scale scaffold and muscle cells at the Griffin Museum of Science and Industry in Chicago, 2024. The machine moves when muscle is stimulated. The museum receives 4-5000 visitors every day. We had our demonstration for 2 days this fall (2024). Our presentation was very popular among all ages.
